item.title: Gas price crisis: Government poised to step in, says Kwarteng
item.description: The government is likely to help big gas providers forced to take customers from failed firms.

item.title: Russia responsible for Litvinenko killing - European court
item.description: Russia responsible for killing of Alexander Litvinenko, spy who died in London of polonium poisoning in 2006, European court finds

item.title: Canada election: Trudeau stays in power but Liberals fall short of majority
item.description: The Canadian prime minister's Liberal Party is projected to form another minority government.

item.title: Afghanistan: MoD shared more than 250 Afghan interpreters' details on email
item.description: Defence Secretary Ben Wallace has launched an investigation, while the MoD has apologised for the breach.

item.title: Children face 'agonising' waits for mental health care
item.description: A BBC investigation finds children in England are facing long waits in pandemic to access services.

item.title: Royals recall Duke of Edinburgh's mustard joke
item.description: The Duke of Cambridge reveals Prince Philip's mustard-squirting antics in a poignant BBC documentary.

item.title: Government borrowing higher than expected in August
item.description: Borrowing was lower than a year earlier, but was still the second-highest on record for August.

item.title: Gabby Petito: FBI searches fiancé Brian Laundrie's home
item.description: Police say Brian Laundrie, who vanished earlier this month, is a "person of interest".

item.title: Climate reporting reaches melting point
item.description: A trip to a melting glacier will shape how the BBC's new climate editor reports on climate change.

item.title: Kidbrooke death: Teacher found dead near community centre named
item.description: The south-east London school where Sabina Nessa worked pays tribute to the "brilliant" teacher.

item.title: Lady Marmalade singer Sarah Dash, of the group Labelle, dies at 76
item.description: Dash was a co-founder of the rock/R&B group Labelle, best known for their 1975 hit Lady Marmalade.

item.title: Newspaper headlines: Gas crisis 'spirals' as 'dozens of firms set to collapse'
item.description: Continuing concerns over soaring gas prices dominate Tuesday's newspaper front pages.

item.title: Community in race to buy remotest mainland pub
item.description: Locals are facing a challenge from potential private buyers to purchase The Old Forge in Knoydart.

item.title: A year in Calais: One migrant’s year-long attempt to cross the Channel
item.description: The BBC followed Iranian migrant Alex, as he tried to cross from France to the UK with a smuggler.

item.title: Can compost help change capitalism?
item.description: John Cossham wants more people to take up composting to encourage a circular economy.

item.title: Nasa selects landing site for Moon rover mission
item.description: The space agency will send a rover to look for water-ice near a crater at the Moon's South Pole.

item.title: RHS Chelsea Flower Show returns for autumnal one-off
item.description: After a year out due to Covid, this year's show is being held four months later than is traditional.

item.title: La Palma volcano: Lava destroys homes in the Canary Islands
item.description: A volcanic eruption on the Spanish island of La Palma has demolished homes and caused evacuations.

item.title: Carol Kirkwood: BBC Weather presenter pulled over by dog on live TV
item.description: Carol Kirkwood says she's fine after taking this tumble on BBC Breakfast when the guide dog went astray.

item.title: Why Serbia has soft spot for late Only Fools actor John Challis
item.description: Only Fools and Horses is hugely popular in Serbia, where tributes have been paid to John Challis.

item.title: Emmy Awards 2021: The Crown and Ted Lasso sweep major categories
item.description: Netflix's royal drama and Apple's comedy series swept the drama and comedy prizes at Sunday's event.

item.title: My husband and son fought in Afghanistan - it changed all of us
item.description: America's two decades in Afghanistan impacted those who served - and the families waiting at home.

item.title: The torso in the Thames: A 20-year mystery
item.description: Twenty years ago, a young African boy was murdered and his torso was dumped in the Thames. It's the longest unsolved child murder case in the recent history of the Metropolitan Police.

item.title: Sex Education: Isaac actor George Robinson gets intimate about disability
item.description: George Robinson on subverting expectations as Isaac - the Netflix show's first disabled character.

item.title: Why is there a CO2 shortage and how will it hit food supplies?
item.description: The food and drink industry is warning of supermarket shortages because of a lack of CO2.

item.title: The mother and son who waited 58 years for a hug
item.description: Calvin Barrett flies from the US to the UK to meet his "Ma" after tracing her through a DNA test.

item.title: Twitch hate raids: Minority streamers have 'a target on their back'
item.description: Streamers tell Newsbeat about the targeted hate they get and what they want Twitch to do about it.

item.title: How 'nerd' culture powered through the pandemic
item.description: Meet the online content creators beating the odds to build successful careers from their passions.

item.title: What if my energy supplier goes bust?
item.description: Gas prices have soared by 250% since January, but what does that mean for household bills?

item.title: Canada election: What you need to know about the campaign
item.description: Canadians are voting on Monday and Justin Trudeau's party faces a stiff challenge to retain power.

item.title: Vunipolas and Ford dropped as England coach Jones calls up Lynagh
item.description: England boss Eddie Jones sets about a major shake-up in his squad by leaving out a host of big names for a training camp later this month.

item.title: Jones loses father's ashes while scoring touchdown
item.description: Aaron Jones honours his late father by scoring four touchdowns as the Green Bay Packers beat the Detroit Lions.

item.title: Usyk 'jumping in at deep end' after two heavyweight fights - Joshua
item.description: Anthony Joshua commends Oleksandr Usyk for "jumping in at the deep end" with a world heavyweight title tilt after just two fights in the class.

item.title: 'It's absurd. We needed England' - men and women's sides withdraw from Pakistan tour
item.description: England withdraw their men's and women's teams from series in Pakistan that were due to take place in October.

item.title: Murray 'not going to wade in with advice' for Raducanu
item.description: Andy Murray says he would "always be on the end of the phone" to give Emma Raducanu help - but only if she asks for it.

item.title: NFL: Aaron Jones scores four TD's for Green Bay against Detroit Lions
item.description: Running back Aaron Jones scores four touchdown for the Green Bay Packers as they beat divisional rivals the Detroit Lions 35-17.

item.title: Travel update: What are the new rules for holidays in Europe and the US?
item.description: The rules on foreign travel to and from England are being simplified.

item.title: Covid rules: What's in England's 'Winter Plan'?
item.description: Lockdown rules have changed across the UK, but some restrictions remain in place.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Universal credit: When will the £20 increase stop?
item.description: The government has confirmed the £20 boost will end in the autumn.

item.title: What are the travel rules for Spain, Portugal, Malta and other holiday hotspots?
item.description: What you need to know about going to Portugal, Spain, Greece, France, Malta, Italy and Turkey.

item.title: Back to school: How are pupils being kept Covid-safe?
item.description: Many children are returning to school after the holidays, while Scottish pupils already returned.

item.title: Covid: People are vaccinated - so why are there so many cases?
item.description: More than four out of five UK adults are now fully vaccinated, but daily case rates remain high.

item.title: Long Covid: What is it and what are the symptoms?
item.description: Significant numbers have had long-term problems after recovering from the original infection.

item.title: Paul Rusesabagina: From Hotel Rwanda hero to convicted terrorist
item.description: Paul Rusesabagina, who was portrayed in Hotel Rwanda, has gone from national hero to enemy of the state.

item.title: Fake Paralympians boss: 'I didn't know about cheating'
item.description: The man fined for sending non-disabled athletes to the Sydney Paralympics breaks his silence.

item.title: Muriel Gardiner: The heiress who saved countless lives
item.description: Muriel Gardiner's courage fighting fascism in Austria inspired an Oscar-winning film. Who was she?

item.title: Hushpuppi - the Instagram influencer and international fraudster
item.description: How Nigerian Ramon Abbas went from a romance scammer to a so-called "Billionaire Gucci Master".

item.title: ‘Havana syndrome ’ and the mystery of the microwaves
item.description: The BBC investigates a mystery illness dubbed "Havana syndrome" that has affected American diplomats and spies.
